context: [1] Benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and xylene (BTEX) are volatile organic compounds (VOCs) commonly found in crude petroleum and petroleum products such as petrol. [2] The main sources of urban VOC pollution are road transport, industrial sources, wood smoke and landfill sites.,, [3] Individuals are also exposed to VOCs indoors at levels often exceeding health benchmarks for outdoor exposure,  with smoking a particular risk. [4] Typical daily exposure has been reported with geometric means in the order of 0.80, 2.8, 0.5 and 2.4 Î¼g/m3 for benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and xylenes, respectively, but there is a large variation in these figures with ranges of up to 23.8, 2120, 119 and 697 Î¼g/m3, respectively, in a sample of 204 subjects from a cross-sectional study in non-occupationally exposed non-smokers. [1] Exposure to VOC air pollution points to an elevated risk of developing chronic respiratory illness. [2] It is possible that endurance athletes may have a greater than average exposure and uptake of air pollutants due to exercise induced increases in ventilation and capillary blood volume. [1] To date, several studies have been undertaken to evaluate the exposure to BTEX in on-road cyclists focusing on ambient air concentrations.,,

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene and toluene are both identified as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) that are commonly found in crude petroleum and petroleum products. They are mentioned together in the context of urban VOC pollution, highlighting their presence in air quality studies and potential health risks associated with exposure. However, the relationship between them is primarily categorical, as they are both part of the BTEX group, without specific interactions or comparative analysis provided in the text.
